analyzeResult.content:
Understanding Drug Addiction: Implications for Treatment
ALAN I. LESHNER National Institute on Drug Abuse
The addicted brain is qualitatively different from the nonaddicted brain, in ways that include glucose use, gene expression, and responsiveness to environmental cues. Such discoveries place researchers in the early but hopeful stages of translating fundamental findings into new treatments that address the neurobiologic basis of drug craving-even for cocaine, against which there are currently no pharmacologic interventions.
Drug addiction is fundamentally a brain disease. This seemingly straightforward observation is ac- tually the outcome of dramatic changes in our un- derstanding of substance abuse. Before the ad- vances, addiction was typically seen as a purely be- havioral disorder, characterized internally by drug craving and externally by compulsive {and harm- ful) drug-seeking behavior. Its chief pathophysio- logic manifestation was the withdrawal syndrome resulting from abstinence. Neurobiologically, how- ever, it is now known that the drug-addicted brain is qualitatively different from the nonaddicted brain, as manifested, for example. by global de- clines in glucose metabolism and intraneuronal changes in gene expression. In effect. a "switch" has been thrown. Although the precise molecular na- ture of the switch remains unknown. current knowledge implicates activation of the brain's mesolimbic dopamine system as a common de- nominator in at least the acute effects of all abused drugs.
Behavioral-science advances have been equally significant. They show that the addicted brain is abnormally conditioned, so that environmental cues surrounding drug use have become part of the addiction. Suspicion of the importance of such cues dates at icast to the era of the Vietnam War. from which roughly 100.000 Americans returned addicted to heroin. In the United States, these per- sons often overcame their addiction with much less distress than is typically the case for American street addicts. The crucial difference appears to have been that the military personnel returned to an environment completely different from the one in which their addiction developed.
Both lines of investigation have implications for
treatment. The neurobiologic advances represent initial efforts to identify the changes induced by chronic substance abuse. and thus to address the physical basis of drug craving. Specific pharmaco- logic intervention would aim to throw the addiction switch back. Meanwhile. the behavioral-science advances emphasize that drug addiction is a brain disease embedded in a social context. Treatment must therefore include deconditioning to extin- guish cues that would otherwise be inducements for relapse. Together, the lines of research point to- ward eventual treatment programs more compre- hensive and more effective than those we currently have.
The Emerging Neurobiology
Among the wealth of findings that now illuminate the basis of drug addiction in the brain, the most elemental. but critical. has been the identification of the molecular sites of action for every major abused drug. Each such drug affects a particular set of cell-surface receptors. transmembrane ion channels, or transmembrane transporter (pump) molecules. For example. opiates bind to the brain's opioid receptors, whereas cocaine binds to the pump molecule responsible for uptake of the neu- rotransmitter dopamine into presynaptic axon ter- minals. To this extent. each abused drug affects its own brain system, establishing the individuality of each such substance-an individuality distinguish- able to drug abusers.
Dr. Leshner is Director. National Institute on Drug Abuse, National Institutes of Health. Rockville. Md.
Copyright & The McGraw-Hill Companies Inc Reprinted with permission Printed in USA
Hospital Practice October 15. 1996
2063336917
